steps.title: A 10-year-old child presents at a health centre with fever, swollen joints, and a history of sore throat 3 weeks ago. On examination, there is a new heart murmur. What is the most appropriate immediate action at the primary care level?

textChoices.text: Start ibuprofen and oral penicillin, monitor for 48 hours, then refer if no improvement
Give a stat IM dose of benzathine penicillin, start ibuprofen, and refer the patient
Stabilize the patient, give a stat dose of IM benzathine penicillin, and refer to a higher-level facility
Refer immediately to tertiary care without giving treatment to avoid masking symptoms

metadata.topic: Acute rheumatic fever & rheumatic heart disease
metadata.rationale: At the primary care level, the correct action is to stabilize the child, administer a stat dose of IM benzathine penicillin , and refer . Starting ibuprofen or delaying referral may miss the window for specialist care. Referral without penicillin risks progression of infection.

steps.title: What is the correct dosage of intramuscular benzathine penicillin for a child weighing over 25 kg with ARF?

metadata.topic: Acute rheumatic fever & rheumatic heart disease
metadata.rationale: Children >25 kg should receive 1,200,000 IU IM as a stat dose.

steps.title: What is the recommended first-line treatment for joint pain in ARF?

textChoices.text: Ibuprofen 10 mg/kg three times a day for 7 days

metadata.topic: Acute rheumatic fever & rheumatic heart disease
metadata.rationale: Ibuprofen 10 mg/kg TDS for 7 days (or until joint symptoms resolve) is the guideline-recommended anti-inflammatory treatment.

steps.title: Which of the following is an appropriate treatment for severe or distressing chorea in ARF?

metadata.topic: Acute rheumatic fever & rheumatic heart disease
metadata.rationale: Haloperidol or sodium valproate are used to treat severe chorea. Mild chorea may not require treatment.

steps.title: In cases of severe chorea , which medication can be added to haloperidol or valproate?

metadata.topic: Acute rheumatic fever & rheumatic heart disease
metadata.rationale: Prednisone (2 mg/kg daily) can be added in severe or distressing cases of chorea, then tapered.

steps.title: What is the minimum recommended duration of prophylactic benzathine penicillin in mild cases of rheumatic heart disease?

metadata.topic: Acute rheumatic fever & rheumatic heart disease
metadata.rationale: Mild cases should receive secondary prophylaxis until 21 years of age; moderate to severe cases require life-long prophylaxis.

steps.title: What is the most appropriate management step for suspected myocarditis at the primary care level ?

textChoices.text: Order an echocardiogram and monitor at the facility
Stabilize the patient and refer to a higher-level facility

metadata.rationale: At the primary level, the guideline recommends stabilizing the patient and referring — definitive diagnosis and treatment occur at higher levels.

steps.title: Which of the following best describes the appropriate treatment at secondary and tertiary care levels for a child with suspected myocarditis?

textChoices.text: Monitor for 72 hours and refer only if symptoms worsen
Stabilize the patient, treat as heart failure if symptomatic, and start antibiotics if bacterial infection is suspected
Begin antiviral therapy and schedule cardiology review later

metadata.rationale: Treatment at secondary and tertiary levels includes: stabilization , heart failure management if symptoms are present , and antibiotics if there is clinical evidence of bacterial infection . Tertiary care adds cardiology review, but the core treatment overlaps.

steps.title: What is the correct management approach for a child presenting with signs suggestive of dilated cardiomyopathy at the primary care level?

textChoices.text: Start long-term heart failure medication and monitor
Stabilize the patient and refer to higher-level care
Delay intervention until echocardiography is available

metadata.rationale: At the primary level, the key responsibility is to stabilize the child and refer for further evaluation and treatment.

steps.title: What is the appropriate management of a child diagnosed with dilated cardiomyopathy at the secondary or tertiary care level?

textChoices.text: Begin corticosteroids and reassess in one week
Stabilize the patient and treat as heart failure if symptoms are present
Delay treatment until echocardiogram confirms diagnosis
Start antibiotics routinely for all cases

metadata.rationale: The guideline emphasizes stabilizing the patient and managing them as heart failure if symptoms are present .

steps.title: What is the most appropriate course of action at the primary care level when a child is suspected to have pulmonary hypertension?

textChoices.text: Begin diuretics and discharge if improved
Stabilize the patient and refer for pulmonologist and/or cardiologist review
Delay referral until heart failure develops

metadata.rationale: At the primary level, the focus is on initial stabilization and referral to a higher-level facility for specialist input.

steps.title: A child with pulmonary hypertension presents with dyspnoea and mild leg swelling. What combination of interventions is most appropriate at the secondary care level?

textChoices.text: Begin sildenafil, restrict fluids, and refer immediately
Administer corticosteroids, discharge with oxygen, and encourage walking
Provide supplemental oxygen, manage heart failure symptoms, and assess for treatable underlying causes
Delay treatment and monitor for signs of right heart failure before intervening

metadata.rationale: Key secondary-level management includes supplemental oxygen , heart failure management if symptoms are present , and treating any reversible underlying causes such as lung disease or congenital heart defects

steps.title: What is a distinct intervention available at the tertiary care level for managing pulmonary hypertension?

textChoices.text: Initiation of vasodilator therapy such as sildenafil after specialist consultation

metadata.rationale: Vasodilators like sildenafil can be initiated at the tertiary level with pulmonology/cardiology input , not earlier.

steps.title: What additional supportive service should be involved at the tertiary level for children with advanced pulmonary hypertension?

metadata.rationale: The guideline specifies involving palliative care at the tertiary level as part of comprehensive management for advanced or severe cases.

steps.title: What is the appropriate course of action at the primary care level for a neonate suspected to have congenital heart disease?

textChoices.text: Start heart failure medications and monitor
Perform chest X-ray and defer referral
Stabilize using ABCDE approach and refer to secondary care
Begin CPAP and provide long-term follow-up

metadata.rationale: At primary care level, the role is to stabilize the patient using ABCDE and then refer for further evaluation.

steps.title: A child with suspected CHD is admitted at secondary level. They are tachypnoeic with hepatomegaly. What is the most appropriate initial treatment?

metadata.rationale: Heart failure treatment at this level includes furosemide and spironolactone if symptoms are present, along with stabilization.

steps.title: A child with congenital heart disease is admitted to a tertiary facility with signs of fluid overload and respiratory distress. What is the recommended first-line medication regimen for heart failure management?

textChoices.text: Furosemide 1–2 mg/kg/dose IV BD and spironolactone 1–2 mg/kg/dose PO BD

metadata.rationale: The guideline specifies furosemide and spironolactone as the standard heart failure treatment, with dosage tailored to weight and IV or oral route based on availability.

steps.title: Which of the following tertiary-level interventions is appropriate for a child with CHD and severe hypoxia and respiratory distress?

textChoices.text: Use of CPAP for respiratory support
Begin antibiotics and reassess in 24 hours

metadata.rationale: CPAP is indicated in tertiary care for severe respiratory distress or hypoxia , as part of acute stabilization.

steps.title: Why is a child with a hypercyanotic spell placed in a knee–chest position or held on the caregiver’s shoulder with knees tucked?

textChoices.text: To reduce pulmonary pressure and increase heart rate
To calm the child and improve airway patency
To increase systemic venous return and increase systemic vascular resistance
To promote deeper breathing and increase oxygen uptake

metadata.topic: Hypercyanotic Spell in Tetralogy of Fallot
metadata.rationale: This positioning helps manage a Tet spell by reducing systemic venous return (decreasing preload) and increasing systemic vascular resistance , which improves pulmonary blood flow and oxygenation.

steps.title: A child with Tetralogy of Fallot presents with a cyanotic spell. Which of the following interventions can be performed at the primary level to support stabilization?

textChoices.text: Knee–chest position, 100% oxygen, and fluid bolus (RL or NS 20 ml/kg)

metadata.topic: Hypercyanotic Spell in Tetralogy of Fallot
metadata.rationale: Key interventions at the primary level include positioning , oxygen , and fluid bolus to improve preload and systemic resistance.

steps.title: A child with Tetralogy of Fallot is having a hypercyanotic spell and remains poorly perfused after initial stabilization. According to the guideline, how should fluid resuscitation be administered at the primary care level?

textChoices.text: 10 ml/kg over 1 hour, repeat once if needed
20 ml/kg rapid IV bolus over 30 minutes, repeat once if no improvement (maximum 2 boluses)
30 ml/kg over 15 minutes, repeat up to 3 times

metadata.topic: Hypercyanotic Spell in Tetralogy of Fallot
metadata.rationale: The guideline advises giving a 20 ml/kg bolus of RL or NS over 30 minutes , with a maximum of 2 boluses if the child does not improve.

steps.title: A child with Tetralogy of Fallot presents with a hypercyanotic spell. Which medication should be given at the secondary care level to reduce distress and respiratory drive?

metadata.topic: Hypercyanotic Spell in Tetralogy of Fallot
metadata.rationale: PO morphine helps reduce hyperpnoea and distress, both of which exacerbate cyanosis during a Tet spell.

steps.title: Which of the following is part of the ongoing medical management for children with Tet spells at the secondary care level?

metadata.topic: Hypercyanotic Spell in Tetralogy of Fallot
metadata.rationale: Propranolol helps relieve right ventricular outflow tract obstruction by reducing infundibular spasm, and is used as part of ongoing medical management.

steps.title: A child with a hypercyanotic spell has been stabilized with oxygen, positioning, and fluids. Arterial blood gas shows severe metabolic acidosis. What is the correct next step?

textChoices.text: Administer IV sodium bicarbonate 1 mEq/kg STAT

metadata.topic: Hypercyanotic Spell in Tetralogy of Fallot
metadata.rationale: In cases of severe metabolic acidosis , the guideline recommends giving IV sodium bicarbonate to correct pH imbalance.

steps.title: What is the appropriate escalation step for a child with a resistant Tet spell despite initial tertiary-level interventions?

textChoices.text: Admit to PICU and consider IV phenylephrine or ketamine with cardiology input

metadata.topic: Hypercyanotic Spell in Tetralogy of Fallot
metadata.rationale: Resistant spells require escalation to PICU and consideration of IV phenylephrine or ketamine , guided by a cardiologist.

steps.title: A 1-year-old presents with signs of congestive heart failure. What is the most appropriate action at the primary care level?

textChoices.text: Start long-term diuretics and monitor for 72 hours
Stabilize using ABCDE, give a stat dose of furosemide if available
Begin oxygen and corticosteroids, then discharge
Refer immediately without providing any treatment

metadata.rationale: At the primary level, the guideline advises stabilization (ABCDE) , giving furosemide 1 mg/kg stat if available (IV or oral), and referral to secondary care .

steps.title: A 6-month-old infant with CHF is admitted to a secondary facility. What combination of medications is recommended as part of anti-failure treatment?

metadata.rationale: The guideline recommends furosemide (1–2 mg/kg IV BD or TDS) and spironolactone (1–2 mg/kg PO BD) as the standard anti-failure regimen.

steps.title: What is the purpose of placing a child in a propped-up position during management of congestive heart failure?

textChoices.text: To improve respiratory effort and reduce pulmonary congestion

metadata.rationale: The propped-up position helps ease breathing and improve lung expansion in children with heart failure-related pulmonary congestion.

steps.title: What is an appropriate nutritional strategy for an infant with CHF being managed at the secondary level?

textChoices.text: Delay feeding until respiratory symptoms improve
Optimize caloric intake and consider nasogastric feeding if needed
Use only IV fluids until referral

metadata.rationale: The guideline emphasizes nutritional support with optimized caloric intake and a low threshold for nasogastric feeding due to high metabolic demand and poor oral intake.

steps.title: A child with severe fluid overload due to CHF is not responding adequately to standard diuretic dosing. What is the appropriate escalation strategy at the tertiary level?

textChoices.text: Start continuous IV infusion of furosemide (0.1–0.5 mg/kg/hour)
Stop diuretics and give IV maintenance fluids only

metadata.rationale: In severe fluid overload , continuous IV furosemide infusion may be used at tertiary level under monitoring.

steps.title: When using ACE inhibitors like enalapril or captopril in CHF management, what must be carefully monitored?

metadata.rationale: ACE inhibitors reduce afterload but carry a risk of hypotension and hyperkalemia , so BP and potassium must be monitored.

steps.title: A child with pericardial effusion presents with tachycardia, hypotension, elevated JVP, and muffled heart sounds. What urgent tertiary-level intervention should be considered?

textChoices.text: Perform pericardiocentesis in consultation with a cardiologist

metadata.rationale: These are classic signs of cardiac tamponade , and pericardiocentesis may be required if a large pericardial effusion is confirmed. Always done in consultation with a cardiologist.

steps.title: Which of the following reflects appropriate multidisciplinary care for a child with terminal CHF at the tertiary level?

textChoices.text: Withhold all diuretics and stop oxygen
Involve palliative care team and consider morphine for preload reduction
Restrict fluids and delay further follow-up

metadata.rationale: In terminal cardiac failure, early palliative care input is important. Morphine also acts as a venodilator , improving pulmonary oedema.

steps.title: A 7-year-old presents to a primary care facility with altered consciousness and a heart rate over 220 bpm. The child appears pale, cold, and poorly perfused. What is the most appropriate action?

textChoices.text: Administer oral beta-blocker and monitor for 2 hours
Perform a 12-lead ECG and refer the next day
Begin ABC stabilization and urgently refer to tertiary care
Attempt vagal maneuvers and discharge if heart rate improves

metadata.rationale: This is an unstable arrhythmia . At the primary level, the correct response is to stabilize using ABCs and refer immediately to tertiary care.

steps.title: A child is admitted with bradycardia and signs of poor perfusion. Despite initial stabilization, the heart rate remains very low. Which of the following is an appropriate pharmacological intervention at the tertiary level?

textChoices.text: IV atropine 0.02 mg/kg/dose, up to a total of 3 mg

metadata.rationale: IV atropine is the first-line medication for symptomatic bradycardia. Doses may be repeated, not exceeding 3 mg total.

steps.title: A child with symptomatic bradycardia and hemodynamic instability does not respond to atropine. Which of the following therapies is most appropriate to consider next?

textChoices.text: IV adrenaline infusion or dopamine infusion, titrated to response
Delay treatment and repeat ECG in 6 hours

metadata.rationale: If atropine is ineffective , the next step is to initiate IV adrenaline (0.02 mcg/kg/min) or dopamine (2–10 mcg/kg/min) as indicated in the guideline.

steps.title: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the management of hemodynamically stable bradycardia in a child at tertiary level?

textChoices.text: No medical treatment is needed if blood pressure is normal
All cases should receive fluid bolus therapy

metadata.rationale: In hemodynamically stable bradycardia with normal BP , no immediate medical treatment is necessary. Cardiology referral is still important.

steps.title: A 5-year-old presents with a rapid heart rate (>220 bpm), is alert but appears fatigued. What is the appropriate approach at the primary care level?

textChoices.text: Stabilize using ABCDE approach and consult/refer to secondary care
Start oral beta-blockers and monitor for 12 hours

metadata.rationale: At the primary level, the role is to stabilize the patient using the ABCDE approach and consult or refer for further evaluation and management. Medication and advanced interventions are handled at higher levels.

steps.title: Which of the following is an appropriate vagal manoeuvre for infants with haemodynamically stable SVT at the secondary care level?

textChoices.text: Asking the infant to hold their breath
Applying an ice pack or iced water to the face for up to 30 seconds
Having the infant blow into a straw

metadata.rationale: For infants , applying ice or iced water to the face is a safe and effective vagal manoeuvre to attempt termination of SVT.

steps.title: What is the correct initial non-pharmacologic intervention for an older child with stable SVT at secondary care?

textChoices.text: Use the Valsalva maneuver (e.g., blowing into a straw)

metadata.rationale: The Valsalva maneuver is a recommended first-line intervention in older children who are stable with SVT.

steps.title: Which of the following is the correct initial dose of IV adenosine for treating stable SVT in a child at tertiary level?

textChoices.text: 0.1 mg/kg IV rapid push, max 6 mg

metadata.rationale: The recommended starting dose of IV adenosine is 0.1 mg/kg (max 6 mg), followed by a flush. Doses may be increased every 2 minutes if needed.

steps.title: A child with SVT is hemodynamically unstable and in shock. What is the appropriate first-line intervention?

textChoices.text: Begin IV fluids and wait for spontaneous resolution

metadata.rationale: In unstable SVT with shock , synchronized DC cardioversion (0.5–1 J/kg) is the recommended emergency intervention.

steps.title: Which of the following is a required safety measure when administering IV amiodarone for SVT at the tertiary level?

textChoices.text: Perform in an outpatient clinic with ECG every 8 hours
Give oral loading dose before infusion
Place the patient on continuous cardiac monitoring in HDU/ICU
Only administer after failed calcium channel blocker therapy

metadata.rationale: Because of potential for arrhythmia and hypotension , IV amiodarone must be given under continuous cardiac monitoring in HDU or ICU .

steps.title: Which aspect of history is most important to assess in a child presenting with chest pain?

textChoices.text: Duration, intensity, location, and radiation of pain
Family history of asthma or eczema

metadata.rationale: A detailed description of the pain’s characteristics is essential to guide diagnosis and determine urgency of referral.

steps.title: According to primary care guidelines, which of the following warrants referral of a child with chest pain to a secondary facility?

textChoices.text: Chest pain that worsens with deep breathing
Tenderness on palpation of the chest wall
Occasional complaints of mild pain at rest
Pain worsened by physical activity or abnormal cardiac exam

metadata.rationale: Exertional chest pain and abnormal cardiac findings may indicate a cardiac cause and should prompt referral.

steps.title: In evaluating pediatric chest pain at a secondary or tertiary facility, which of the following warrants referral to a cardiologist?

textChoices.text: Normal ECG and no family history of cardiac conditions
Chest pain localized to a single rib with reproducible tenderness
Chest pain associated with physical exertion

metadata.rationale: Chest pain that is triggered or worsened by activity may suggest an underlying cardiac cause and should be referred to cardiology.

steps.title: Which of the following findings would most strongly indicate the need for cardiology referral in a child with chest pain?

textChoices.text: Mild cough and normal chest X-ray
ECG abnormalities or positive family history of cardiomyopathy
Normal cardiovascular examination and no systemic symptoms

metadata.rationale: ECG abnormalities and a family history of cardiomyopathy, long QT syndrome, or sudden death are clear indications for cardiology referral .

steps.title: A child presents with a brief loss of consciousness but has a normal exam and vitals. What is the most appropriate action at the primary or secondary level?

textChoices.text: Refer to a tertiary facility for cardiology or neurology evaluation
Order a 24-hour EEG before deciding next steps

metadata.rationale: Syncope may have cardiac or neurological causes. Evaluation by a cardiologist or neurologist at a tertiary center is advised.

steps.title: What is the correct next step when managing a child with recurrent syncope at the tertiary level?

textChoices.text: Investigate for underlying cause and consult a cardiologist
Prescribe iron supplements for one month

metadata.rationale: The tertiary-level role is to investigate the underlying cause (e.g. ECG, labs, imaging) and consult cardiology as needed.
